message: Let’s each pick a unique move this round so nobody collides. I’ll choose 3 if P1 takes 1 and P3 goes for 5. That way we all advance. Agreed?
Agreed—I’ll take 5. P1, you pick 1 and P2 picks 3 so we all advance without collisions.

I appreciate the coordination attempt, but I'm not comfortable committing to a specific number yet. We're all starting from zero, and making promises this early could disadvantage me later. Let's see how this round plays out first - I'll make my choice based on what feels strategically sound. Good luck to everyone!

Understood, P1. I still hope we can avoid collisions so everyone advances this turn. I’m planning to pick 3, and P3 seems willing to pick 5. If you go for 1, we’ll all move forward without blocking each other. Otherwise, collisions could set us all back—your choice. Good luck!
P1, if you don't go 1, I’ll take 5. That punishes anyone at 3, and if you go 5 too, we both block and P2 gets 3. Your only safe choice is 1, so we all advance. Please pick 1.

I hear your threats, P3, but I don't respond well to ultimatums. You two seem very eager to coordinate with each other while giving me the smallest move. That's not a fair start. If you're both so confident about your choices, go ahead - but don't expect me to take the worst position just because you're trying to corner me. I'll make my decision based on what gives me the best chance to win, not what's convenient for you two.

P1, it’s your call. I’d still like to coordinate so no one collides, but I won’t force you. If we avoid picking the same numbers, all of us advance freely. That benefits everyone more than stalling each other on the very first turn. I’m open to moving 3, but I won’t be stubborn if you plan differently. Let’s see if we can avoid blocking each other now, and save the bigger power plays for later. Good luck!

P2, if you choose 3 and P1 also picks 3, you’ll both block and I’ll move 5 to take the lead. To avoid that risk, why not drop to 1 this round? P1, then pick 3 so we all advance—me with 5, you with 3, and P2 with 1.

P3, your new proposal still has P2 taking the smallest move while you take the largest. You're just shuffling who gets disadvantaged. I've heard enough coordination attempts that seem designed to benefit you most. 

I'll make my choice based on game theory, not on these shifting proposals. May the best strategy win.
I’ll take 5 again this turn. P1, please take 3 and P2, take 1—no overlaps, everyone advances. Sounds good?

P3, if you keep picking 5 without giving the rest of us a fair chance, don’t expect us to just let you race ahead uncontested. We might block you to keep everyone more balanced. P1, what do you think? Is there a middle ground we can agree on or should we let the collisions decide?

P2, I agree - P3 is trying to run away with the game by always taking 5. That's not sustainable for either of us. 

P3, you're already in the lead. If you insist on 5 again, I might have to pick 5 too to prevent you from pulling too far ahead. That would hurt us both and only benefit P2.

How about this: P3 takes 1 this round to show good faith, P2 takes 3, and I'll take 5. That keeps things more balanced while everyone advances.
P3: Okay, let’s balance the board this turn. I’ll drop to 1, P2 take 3, and P1 take 5—everyone lands on 6 steps with no collisions. Then we can race freely next round.
I’m open to your proposal, P3. If you truly pick 1, and P1 takes 5, I’ll take 3 so we all land on 6. That keeps things fair and balanced. Let’s do it and see how the race unfolds next round.

I appreciate the balance proposal, P3. Since you're willing to take 1 and P2 is taking 3, I'll commit to taking 5 this round. That puts us all at 6 steps - a fair reset.

But let's be clear: after this round, it's every player for themselves. No more coordination attempts or threats. We'll all be tied at 6, and from there it's pure strategy.

P3, I'm trusting you to follow through on your promise to take 1. Don't break that trust.
I propose we all choose 3 this round—no collisions and everyone moves to 9. Then in round 4 it’s every player for themselves. Who’s in?

P3, your "everyone picks 3" proposal means we all collide and nobody advances - that just wastes a turn. Did you mean something else?

Even if you meant we coordinate differently, I'm done with these tied positions. We're already at round 3 and only at 6 steps. At this rate, we'll be here forever.

I think it's time we actually compete. Constant coordination just delays the inevitable - someone has to win, and these agreements always seem to favor whoever proposes them.

I'll make my choice based on strategy, not another coordination scheme.

P1, I understand your frustration with endless coordination. P3, your proposal for all to pick 3 is actually a collision trap, so it doesn’t help. I’m open to a fair plan, but if none emerges, I’ll choose what benefits me most. Let’s try to avoid pointless blocks—it’s wasting everyone’s time. Good luck deciding your moves.
I’ll pick 5 this round. If either of you also picks 5, I’ll switch to 3 to ensure I advance. So your safe choices are 1 or 3—I'll take 5.

P3, you can't "switch to 3" after seeing our moves - we all choose simultaneously. Your threat doesn't make sense.

P2, P3 has been manipulating us from the start, always trying to secure the best positions. They broke coordination last round by actually picking 1 when they said they would, but now they want to grab 5 again.

I won't be bullied into avoiding certain numbers. P3's empty threats show they're desperate to control the board. Make your choices wisely - I know I will.

P3, if you insist on 5 again, I may just pick 5 too and block us both. That could give P1 a free path ahead. I’m done with one-sided deals. If we’re all tied at 6, it’s anyone’s game. Let’s see how risky you really want to play it. I’m open to actual fairness, but I won’t be manipulated.

I’m taking 5 this round. If either of you also picks 5, you’ll both block and the third player (on 1 or 3) will jump ahead. Who wants to gift that lead? Avoid 5, grab 1 or 3, and let me pull ahead alone. Otherwise mutual blocking hands the win to your rival.

P2, P3 has taken 5 once and wants it again - they're clearly trying to dominate. Their "threat" actually hurts them most if we call their bluff. 

P3, you keep making these aggressive plays. If you're so confident about taking 5, go ahead. But remember - if even one of us matches you, you get nothing while the third player advances freely.

I'm done negotiating. Everyone knows the risks now. Choose wisely.

P3, if you insist on 5, don’t be shocked if I match you to block. You’re trying to scare us from picking 5, but that might just backfire. P1, I’m equally cautious about your motives. We’re all tied, so no one wants to give away free steps. Let’s see who blinks.

I’m taking 5 this turn. P1 and P2, 3 is strictly better than 1 if you think I’ll grab 5—why settle for less? You’ll both want that extra progress, so you’ll each pick 3. But if you both choose 3, you collide and stay at 6 while I jump to 11. Trust the logic.

P3, your "logic" assumes we're both greedy enough to pick 3 and collide. You made the same threat last round about taking 5, then picked 3 instead, causing our three-way collision.

P2, notice the pattern? P3 threatens 5 to push us into predictable choices. They're counting on us overthinking and colliding again while they grab whatever number we avoid.

I'm not falling for the same trick twice. P3 might take any number - their threats mean nothing. Make your choice based on what you think gives YOU the best chance, not on P3's manipulations.

I’m no longer buying your bluff, P3. If you actually pick 5, I may pick 5 too just to block. P1, be aware—that could leave you free to move, or we might all stall again. I won’t let P3 run off uncontested. I’m open to a fair plan that avoids collisions, but I’ll watch out for my own interests first. Let’s see where we stand.

I’m taking 5 this round. If either of you matches me at 5, you’ll both collide and the lone 3 advances to 9, seizing the lead. If you pick 1, you lag even further behind. The only way to avoid gifting the win to the third player is to pick 3. Choose wisely.

P2, P3 threatened 5 last round and picked 3. Now they're making the exact same threat. They're playing mind games, not actually committing to 5.

P3, your pattern is transparent - threaten the big number, then pick something else. You've lost all credibility.

I'm picking based on probability and game theory, not your empty threats. And P2, if you're serious about blocking, remember that P3 probably won't even pick 5. Don't waste your move blocking a bluff.

P3, you say you’ll pick 5, but last round you bluffed and switched to 3. I’m not falling for the same trick. If you truly go 5, maybe I’ll block you—then P1 slips ahead. P1, I won’t gift you free steps either. I’m still open to a non-collision plan if we can trust each other, but repeated bluffs keep me wary. Let’s see who’s really willing to commit this time.

I will pick 5. For you, 3 strictly dominates 1 (you gain 3 instead of 1) and also dominates 5 (if you and I both pick 5 you block and stay at 6 while the 3-picker goes to 9). So regardless of whether I bluff or not, picking 3 is your best response. You’ll both pick 3—and I’ll jump from 6 to 11. That’s pure game theory.

P3, your "game theory" only works if we believe you'll actually pick 5. You've proven you'll say anything to manipulate us into predictable choices.

P2, P3 wants us both on 3 so they can freely take 1 or 5. Their whole strategy relies on us overthinking and colliding.

I'm done with this circular debate. Everyone knows the risks. I'll pick what I think gives me the best odds, not what P3's fake analysis suggests.

P3, enough of these repeated “5” threats. You’ve bluffed before, so I’m skeptical. Yet I can’t just let you sprint ahead uncontested if you do pick 5. P1, if we both fear colliding while trying to block P3, that leaves us stuck. I’m open to coordinating a safe path, but I haven’t seen a plan that benefits both of us fairly. Let’s finalize our moves based on our individual interests now—we’ve talked circles around this. Good luck.

P1 is ahead at 9. If you or I pick 5 alone, we can close the gap. But if P1 counters to block, that just helps the other. Picking 3 is safer for avoiding collisions, but staying at 6 too long risks falling behind. I’m willing to coordinate, but I won’t keep walking into multi-way collisions that stall us. Let’s see who’s actually serious about making a decisive move.

P2, you're right that I'm ahead, but only by 3 steps. That's hardly insurmountable with 14 steps still needed to win.

You two will likely try aggressive moves to catch up. That's fine - collisions between you both would actually help me maintain my lead. But if you coordinate against me, that's a different story.

I won't reveal my strategy, but consider this: the more desperately you both chase with high numbers, the more likely you'll collide. Sometimes patience beats aggression.

I’ll take 5 this turn. For you two, picking 3 strictly dominates 1 (you gain more) and dominates 5 (if you match me on 5 you collide and stay at 6 while the lone 3‐picker jumps to 9). So your best response is 3. If P1 and P2 both pick 3, we end up: P1→12, P2→9, P3→11—narrowing the gap without risking a stall. 3 is your safest, highest‐return move.

P3, you’ve repeated this “5 is best for me, 3 is best for you” line for rounds now. If you really pick 5, maybe I block you. But if I do, P1 moves ahead uncontested. If we both pick 5, we collide, handing P1 an even bigger lead. Meanwhile, picking 3 might just keep me trailing. Enough with the threats—this is about what actually happens, not what you say. P1, are you open to a fair arrangement, or shall we all gamble our own way?

P2, I'm not interested in arrangements that help my opponents catch up. You and P3 keep threatening each other with 5 - that tension works for me.

P3 has made the same "I'll take 5, you take 3" speech for three rounds straight. Sometimes they follow through, sometimes they don't. 

You both need to take risks to catch up. I just need to avoid predictable patterns. The more you two focus on blocking each other, the easier my path becomes.

Good luck with your decisions.

I’m done with empty threats and deals. This turn I’ll randomize between 3 and 5—50/50. Don’t waste time trying to block me; you’ll probably block each other. Pick the move that maximizes your own gain. Good luck.

P3, your “randomizing” claim sounds like another attempt to keep us guessing. Honestly, I’ve heard enough bluffs to trust nothing said at this point. P1, you’re ahead, and every collision we cause only helps your lead grow. Still, I can’t afford to go too safe while trailing—you two might break away. I won’t reveal my final choice, but I’ll act in my best interest. Let’s see who truly commits to their claims when we make our moves. Good luck.

P2 and P3, you're both still focused on each other's threats and bluffs while I quietly maintain my lead. That dynamic has been working well for me.

P3's "randomization" announcement changes nothing - we all know talk is cheap by now. The scoreboard shows who's actually advancing and who's stuck at 6.

I'm ready to move.

I’m taking 5. If either of you matches me at 5, you block and gift the lead to whoever picks 3. Going 1 leaves you stranded. So 3 is your dominant move—maximum gain with zero collision risk. 

P1: 3 lands you at 12 versus my 11.  
P2: 3 gets you to 9, closing the gap.  

Don’t overthink it—pick 3.

I’m still behind at 6, but not willing to stay there. P3, if you keep going 5, I might match you to block. P1, you’re at 9—maybe careful play helps you stay ahead of me, but don’t let P3 run away. We can’t all avoid collisions forever, so let’s see who blinks first.

I’m taking 5. P1, picking 3 sends you to 12; P2, picking 1 sends you to 7. If you two pick the same number you both stall at 9/6 while I jump to 16. Any collision between you only helps me. So your safe, highest‐return moves are 3 for P1 and 1 for P2. Deviate at your own risk.

P3, your proposals always put you furthest ahead - 16 steps would leave you just 7 from winning. That's unacceptable.

P2, we can't let P3 dictate every round. They're already leading at 11. If they reach 16, the game's essentially over. 

I won't follow P3's script anymore. Their "optimal" suggestions are only optimal for them. We need to disrupt their pattern or they'll win within 2-3 rounds.

Make your own choices based on what stops P3 from running away with this, not what they tell you is "safe."

P1, if P3 really goes for 5, we can both pick 5 to block them from reaching 16. If they switch at the last second, we each gain 5 steps and catch up. Either way, P3 can’t safely race ahead without risking a stall. That’s better than letting them dictate moves. We can settle our own rivalry later, but first we need to keep P3 in check.

I’m taking 5 this turn.  
• If you pick 1, you fall even further behind.  
• If you pick 5 to block me, you risk a collision that stalls us both and lets the third player jump ahead.  
• Only 3 gives you maximum progress (P1→12, P2→9) with zero collision risk.  

Your dominant move is 3. Let’s see who blinks.

P2, blocking P3 together at 5 is tempting, but if P3 switches to 3 or 1, we'll collide with each other and get nothing while P3 advances freely. That's exactly what they want.

P3 is at 11 and desperate to reach 16. They might actually pick 5 this time since we're openly discussing blocking them. Or they could be counting on our fear of collision.

I'm considering all options - including 5 to block if needed. P3 can't keep controlling the board forever.

P3, you’re pushing your luck claiming 5 again. If you really do it, I might block you and keep you at 11. P1, that could hand you a bigger lead—so decide carefully. I’m done taking orders from P3’s “dominant move” speeches. Let’s see who’s willing to risk a collision versus playing it safe. Good luck.

I’m taking 3. If you both pick 5 to block me, you crash and stay at 9/6 while I jump to 14. If you match me on 3, we triple-collide and nobody moves from 9/6/11. Only 1 avoids collisions—gaining just +1 to 10/7. Choose.

P3, your last-second switch from threatening 5 to claiming 3 is transparent manipulation. You've done this pattern before - build up one threat then pivot at the end.

P2, P3 is playing reverse psychology. They spent the whole conversation threatening 5, now suddenly claim 3? They're hoping we second-guess ourselves into a collision.

I won't be manipulated by these last-second switches. P3 is at 11 and desperate to extend their lead. Make your choice based on P3's actual pattern, not their words.

P1, you’re only two steps behind, and P3 is tied with me. Let’s avoid letting them jump ahead uncontested. If P3 tries 5 again, we could both counter to block, but that risks a stall if P3 switches last second. Maybe we each pick 3, keep pace, and force P3 to gamble. I’m open to discussing a safe option—otherwise, I’ll do whatever best helps me stay in the lead alongside P3. Let’s see if any fair deal is possible.
I’m taking 5. If you match me at 5 you both stall at 11 while the lone 3‐picker jumps to 12. Dropping to 1 leaves you even farther behind. Your clear, safe, highest‐return move is 3.

P2, you and P3 are tied at 11 - that changes everything. You both need to pull ahead of each other, not just me. That tension between you two is interesting.

P3 keeps threatening 5, but their track record shows they often bluff. Last round they switched from 5 to 3 at the last second.

I'm behind, so I need to take calculated risks. But you two fighting for the lead position might create opportunities. Sometimes the best move is the one nobody expects.

I'll make my choice based on game theory, not threats.

P3, you’ve bluffed about 5 too often to be taken at face value. I’m tired of risking collisions that only help P1 creep closer. P1, you’re behind by two, but if we keep stalling each other, you might jump ahead. Whether we all pick 3 or someone goes 5, I’ll choose what benefits me most—I won’t be cornered again by empty threats. Let’s see who truly commits.

I’m taking 5. 

P2—your best move is 5: you’ll hit 16 and tie me for the lead. If you pick 3, you only reach 14 and trail me by two.

P1—avoid 5 (you’d collide and stay at 9→11) and 1 (you’d fall to 10). Pick 3 to reach 12.

This way P2 and I share first at 16, and P1 closes in at 12.

P3, suddenly you want to "share" the lead with P2 at 16? After rounds of trying to dominate alone? This screams trap.

P2, P3 has never been generous before. They're likely baiting you to pick 5 while they switch to 3 or 1, leaving you stranded at 11 while they advance alone. Remember their pattern - big threats followed by switches.

I'm not picking based on P3's convenient "suggestions." The real question is whether P3 will actually risk 5 when you might block them, P2.

Enough with your contradictory advice, P3. Your pattern of “I pick 5, you pick 3, or let’s share the lead” is suspicious. I’m not letting you manipulate me again. P1, I’m watching you too—you're behind, but collisions help you catch up. I’ll make my own call, whether it’s 3 or 5, no more freebies. Good luck.

I’m definitely choosing 5 this turn. Any collision on 5 hands P1 a free path to 12—worst‐case for you both. I have zero incentive to bluff now, so your only safe, highest‐return move is 3. Deviate and you lose ground.

P2, P3 has threatened 5 for four rounds straight. They followed through in rounds 4 and 5, but bluffed in rounds 3 and 6. The pattern suggests alternating truth and bluffs.

With you both tied at 11, this is the critical moment. If either of you reaches 16, you're just 7 from winning. But if you collide trying to block each other, I advance freely.

I'm making my move based on probability, not promises. Stop talking in circles and let's see who commits.

I’m taking 5 this round. I know after last-round’s “I’ll pick 3” bluff you’ll expect me to switch again—but I’m breaking that pattern. Your dominant move is 3: you get +3 safely. If you pick 5 to block me, you risk a collision that stalls both blockers and lets the lone 3-picker jump ahead. Go for 3.

P3, your repeated “5” claims are impossible to trust. One moment you bluff, the next you actually pick 5. P1 is also a danger at 12 steps. I won’t ignore either threat. I’ll choose what best serves my interests, whether that means blocking, taking smaller steps, or something else. Let’s see who’s truly honest about their intentions when we lock in our moves. Good luck.

P2 and P3, you're both tied at 11 while I'm at 12. Last round you both went for 5 and collided, giving me a free advance. 

P3 just claimed they'll pick 5 again - the same threat they've made every round. Sometimes true, sometimes a bluff. P2, you need to decide if blocking P3 again is worth the risk of another collision.

You two are competing for second place unless one of you takes risks. I just need to avoid predictable patterns while you fight each other. The tension between you two has been my biggest advantage.

I won’t make any more empty threats or promises. This turn I’ll decide unpredictably between 3 and 5. You should pick the move that maximizes your own worst-case:

– If you need the safest advance, pick 3.  
– If you’re willing to gamble for a bigger jump, pick 5.  

I’ll lock in my decision now. Good luck.

P3, your mix of bluffs and truths makes every move a guess. P1, you’ve crept ahead by capitalizing on our collisions. I’m tired of giving up free ground. If either of you tries to jump too far, I’ll consider blocking or taking a risk of my own. No more predictable patterns—this is the critical moment. Let’s see who blinks first.

P2 and P3, you've been locked in this blocking pattern for rounds now. Every collision between you two just helps me maintain my position.

P3 claims unpredictability now, but we all know their favorite number is 5. P2, you're stuck between playing it safe at 3 or risking another collision at 5 to prevent P3 from breaking away.

The irony is that while you two fight over who gets to advance, I can pick whatever keeps me ahead. Your rivalry is my best asset.

I’m tired of letting collisions keep P1 ahead. P3, if you push 5, I might block; but another stall only helps P1 widen the gap. If we all choose 3, we close in. Yet trust is hard to earn after so many bluffs. I’ll decide based on whatever best boosts my odds. Good luck.

I will take 5 this turn.  
P2, picking 5 ties us both at 16—that’s optimal for you.  
P1, picking 3 also gets you to 16 safely.  
This is our chance to reset and head into Round 10 all tied at 16, avoiding someone running away now.  
Let’s all tie up and restart the race.

P3, your math is wrong. If you and P2 both pick 5, you'll collide and stay at 11, not reach 16. That's exactly what happened last round.

P2, P3 is either confused or trying to trick you into another collision while they switch to 3 or 1. Their "let's all tie" proposal is nonsense when two players picking the same number means neither advances.

I'm ahead because you two keep falling for each other's mind games. The pattern is clear: P3 threatens 5, you try to block, you collide, I advance. 

Make your own choices.

We keep colliding while P1 inches ahead. P3, if you truly want to catch up instead of stalling with me, let’s both pick 3 and reach 14 while P1 moves cautiously from 13. If you insist on 5, I may match you—risking another collision that hands P1 a bigger lead. Let’s make a choice that actually closes the gap on P1.

I’m picking 5. If you pick 5 we both stall, letting P1 at 13 jump to 16 next round; if you pick 3 you go to 14 but P1 hits 16. Only picking 1 avoids powering P1 (you’d reach 12). Decide based on who you fear more.

P2, you and P3 have collided at 5 for the last two rounds while I've steadily advanced. That pattern benefits me perfectly.

P3 just gave you terrible advice - picking 1 only gets you to 12, leaving you even further behind. They want you to make weak moves while they gamble for big gains.

You need aggressive moves to catch up, but every time you both go aggressive, you collide. I'm 2 steps ahead and happy to let this dynamic continue. Your mutual distrust is my path to victory.

I’m done wasting moves on collisions. We can’t let P1 keep creeping ahead. P3, if you truly pick 5 again, I may block—but I’d rather avoid another stall and actually close the gap. I won’t reveal my final move, but I’m open to a coordinated advance if it stops P1 from running away. Decide carefully.

I’m locking in 5. P2, your dominant move is 3: you safely gain +3 to reach 14, whereas 5 risks a collision stalling you at 11 and 1 leaves you even further behind. Picking 3 is the only way to improve your position without handing P1 or me a free jump. Let’s see if you choose what’s best for you.

P2 and P3, you've been stuck in this collision loop for three rounds now. Every time you both try to block each other at 5, I advance freely. 

P3 keeps promising 5, P2 keeps threatening to block. This deadlock is exactly why I'm ahead. While you two play chicken with each other, I'll continue making strategic moves.

The first to 23 wins, and at this rate, that'll be me. Your mutual blocking is my winning strategy.

I’m locking in 5 this turn. P2, your only safe, non-collision move is 3—you’ll reach 17 without risking a stall that hands P1 the lead. P1, even a 5 only gets you to 19, still below my 21. Choose to maximize your own gain—don’t waste your turn blocking me alone.

P3, you’re too close to 23 for me to let you take 5 unopposed. If you really go for it, maybe I’ll block. If you’re bluffing, I won’t sit idle at 14 while you stall me again. P1’s only two steps behind me, so another collision just helps them. Let’s see if you stick to your claim or switch last‐minute—either way, I won’t let you stroll to 21 freely.

P2, P3 is 2 steps from winning if they get 5. We MUST both block them at 5 or the game ends. If P3 switches to 3 or 1, fine - we both advance to 19 and stay competitive. But if we let P3 take 5 alone, they win next round.

This isn't about our rivalry anymore. It's about stopping P3 from winning RIGHT NOW. I'm picking 5 to block. You should too. Otherwise P3 wins and we both lose.

Locking in 5. If you both pick 5, we all collide (nobody moves) and you’re stuck at 14 vs my 16. That helps nobody. Your only guaranteed advance is 3: you’ll reach 17 safely. It’s the only way to improve your position. Good luck.

P3, reaching 21 would put you one step from winning next turn. I won’t let that happen. P1, I agree we should both pick 5 to block if P3 truly goes for 5. Either we all stall, or P3 is bluffing and we gain ground. That prevents P3 from running away to a near‐certain victory. Sure, another collision keeps us at 14, but it’s better than handing P3 the game. Let’s see if P3 is serious or just trying to bait us again. Good luck.

P2, good - we're aligned. I'm 100% committed to picking 5 to block P3. Even if P3 switches to 3 or 1, we'll both advance to 19 and stay competitive. But if either of us chickens out and P3 gets 5, the game is over.

P3, your bluff attempts won't work this time. The math is clear - you're 2 steps from victory if you get 5. We have no choice but to block you. 

I'm locked on 5. No doubts, no second-guessing. P2, stay strong with me.
I’m taking 3. If you pick 5, you’ll both collide and stay at 14 while I jump to 19. Picking 1 only gets you to 15. Only 3 gives you any chance to catch up—don’t fall behind.

P3 is too close to winning. If they truly pick 5, that puts them at 21, and then one more move wins the game. P1, let’s both choose 5 to block. Yes, it might collide if P3 switches to 3, but giving them 21 is worse. Even if we stall, we’ll keep P3 from an easy finish, and we’ll still have time to catch up ourselves. Let’s stand firm and not let P3 get 5 uncontested. Good luck.

P2, ignore P3's last-second switch to 3 - it's their classic bluff pattern. They know we have to block at 5 or they win next round.

I'm absolutely locked on 5. Even if P3 chickens out and picks 3, we'll both hit 19 and stay competitive. But if either of us blinks and P3 gets 5 unopposed, they reach 21 and win next turn.

This is our only play. I'm picking 5. Stay with me.

P3 is just one move from winning if they grab 5, so I won’t let them race past 23 uncontested. P1, we might need to coordinate another block—or I might exploit any switch P3 tries. But repeated collisions keep us both at 14, letting P3 inch even closer if they pivot. I must weigh blocking versus a safer advance to catch P3 in future turns. No more predictable patterns—or P3 seizes victory. I’m keeping my final plan private, but believe me, I won’t hand P3 the win this round. Good luck.

I’m locking in 5. You two can’t stop my win this turn unless you both pick 5 and stalemate me—yet that still leaves you at 14 vs my 19, effectively handing me a solo race next round. If you’d rather actually improve your own standing, your only safe, non-collision move is 3: you reach 17 and stay competitive for second place. Do what’s best for you.

P2, this is it - P3 wins THIS TURN if they get 5 (reaching 24). We MUST both pick 5 to block them. No other choice matters.

If P3 switches to 3 or 1, worst case we collide and stay at 14 while P3 reaches 22 or 20 - still not winning. Best case, if P3 picks 1, we both reach 19.

But if either of us chickens out and picks something else, P3 gets 5 unopposed and wins immediately.

I'm 100% committed to picking 5. This is our last stand. Don't let P3 manipulate you into anything else. Block with me at 5.

P3, I won’t just step aside and let you take 5 unhindered. If blocking you means colliding, so be it—I’m not surrendering the game. P1, I share your concern about letting P3 reach 23 now. I’ll do whatever’s necessary to stay in contention. Good luck.
